segments.text: Describe his manner of leadership.
Very congenial.
Had a few basic meetings with all the departments.
Would sometimes come to our own particular faculty meeting and share his view.
We were always made to feel important.
He made us all feel important and he shared
If he had something, some publications on foundations, he would send them to me, and I suspect he did that to everybody in the field, his wide reading.
But he was a leader that allowed more freedom, I think, for the faculty, slightly more freedom.
How much of him did you see physically?
Not a lot, no.
We were all so busy in our own little worlds that we kept—but he was always available.
I think he had some sessions up on the eighth floor to talk to people and share ideas.
Very accessible.
Who were the key members of his staff?
I think he continued having Ritchie as a secretary and Brian Cole.
Okay.
What role did Brian play, really?
Was he kind of the chief of staff?
I pictured him as that.
Of course, he has a West Point background, so that would fit.
But Brian is just a remarkable person, and I think we're very lucky to have him as a
person in the background.
Very efficient.
Everything he does is well done.
But he complimented Dean Corrigan.
Meanwhile, over at the presidential level, Dr. Williams had been replaced by Jarvis Miller and then Frank Vandiver and so forth.
How did you and your colleagues, what did you all think about these changes at the presidential level?
Did that affect education much?
I don't think it affected education.
We were all very sorry.
Of course, Williams went to be chancellor, but we lost his input here.
I always liked Jarvis Miller.
As I say, I was president of TAC, the Texas Association of College Teachers, when he
came and he joined us, which was, I thought, very nice because a lot of administrators thought that was a little subversive.
But it was really an organization to help faculty, faculty standards.
I believe that he wanted all the faculty to be in their office all the time.
I'm not sure about my facts on that now, but he saw a man, was he in history, that was running around all the time in shorts?
He died a few years ago.
Lloyd Taylor.
Lloyd Taylor, fine man.
But he saw somebody running when it was not the noon hour.
That's a rumor I heard.
But I always liked him very much.
And Vanderveer, of course, was an outstanding president.
Again, I was president of TAC that year.
and we had trouble getting him to speak to us.
He was so busy.
I remember there were a lot of times where he had to cancel out, but he always helped with tech.
Now that's a general faculty organization.
As far as the College of Education is concerned, I don't believe there was any
feeling that there was a change.
They were always supportive.
Let's see, so you served under how many deans?
Only two, really?
You mean of education?
Well, I believe that Limbacher was— Oh, I forgot Phil.
Phil Limbacher was— So Hubert, and then Limbacher— Limbacher.
And then— And then Dean Corrigan.
Okay.
And then about the time I was retiring, it was Lady Dean and I— Yeah, but that was very brief.
Yes, I was half-time and then retired.
And then Dean Connolly now, who's a very lovely lady.
Looking at the presidential level, I'm not going to ask you the negative, to which presidents would you give highest grades that you served under?
Oh, President Williams.
Yes, without question.
A historic figure, I think, in the history of higher education.
Just a fine man.
Now, he's buried at Clemson, isn't he?
Yes.
My children went to Clemson.
They never sold the first house they built as junior faculty members, and when he died in Houston, Mrs. Williams then went back to that house, and that's where she's living now.
Well, if I get back to Clemson one time, I'll see if I can check with her.
Oh, she'd be delighted to see you.
She's still bright as can be.
Well, I can't remember anyone better.
I served under some good college presidents, Gideons of Brooklyn.
I brought that folder of his inauguration.
You probably have copies of that.
I was also a delegate for Miller's inauguration.
As I say, after Miller retired, I knew him where my mother was at Walden, the retirement home.
He did a very nice job there.
Did you go to commencements very often at A&M?
Yes, and I got tired of counting all the bodies that were going by.
Describe, make believe I had never been to an A&M commencement.
Describe an A&M commencement.
Well, it's really part of the tradition where you go, we take turns, we would get
our gowns on and get lined up.
The students were lined up in mass.
It was a marvelous maneuver.
Then we would march in and sit up in front.
Then we had the name calling.
What was that man that had such a nice voice?
In physical education.
Yeah.
I see him around.
Well, anyway, his voice would ring and he would get
the most unusual names pronounced correctly somehow.
But it was rather an endless procession.
Roger Fellman.
Roger Fellman, wonderful man, Roger Fellman.
But we would get this procession, and of course as faculty all eyes were on us, so we had to keep pretty alert.
But instead, I always thought that being a professor was less a profession than a procession.
What did you and your colleagues do to stay awake while all of the graduates' names were being called out?
Well, I sometimes would figure out how many a minute would pass, and I would work on little formulas to see if I could pick up the right number.
I also went to graduations as part of the audience, too, and the advantage of that was you could see what the students had written on their hats.
Do you remember any?
They were always there for jobs.
high bomb or something like that.
If you were behind them, you could see that.
As a faculty member, you didn't get to see the top of their head.
Of course, we knew what was in their heads.
My favorite was the one that a kid put up one day, Hell Froze Over.
Oh, that's a good one.
Do you remember any commencement speakers?
You know, I can't even remember what was said.
I'm sure that, did you speak one time?
Yes.
I think I remember.
That was the day before Jarvis failed to shake hands with Melanie Zintracht.
I was not at that occasion.
That was Saturday.
I spoke on Friday afternoon.
Well, I may have.
By the way, you spoke at the Kappa Delta Pi one time.
I found the folder.
Oh, my goodness, a lot of it.
If you need it for your biographer.
Oh, oh.
All right, well, let me mention, any kind of material like that, if you ever want to get rid of it, please pass it on to the archives.
Right, and they also ask me for course material sometimes too, and I haven't gotten that put together.
Yes, because otherwise things like that get thrown away.
And here's a repository that will be there forever.
Do you remember the Rudder Lecture Series?
Yes.
I've got some newspaper clippings on that, too, if you'd like to have them.
Oh, yes.
Oh, yes.
I'll dig them out.
All right.
Remember when we had President Williams and we were waiting for Jacques Barzun?
He was still on the – he wouldn't fly, and we were trying to hold the audience and
Yours truly had to go meet him in a car.
You were in the car.
I was with President Williams, and we were trying to talk, and we kept giving word to the audience that we had just heard they were coming in through Caldwell or something like that.
I guess you must have been calling.
He's just been elected to the Texas Institute of Letters.
He has retired and lives in San Antonio now.
I think that he just wrote this powerful book, didn't he?
The History of the World or something.
I haven't seen it yet.
I just loved his lectures, but he never submitted the manuscripts, did he?
No, he would not do so.
Well, I have the newspaper clippings if you would like them.
Yes.
Other lecturers you remember, other visitors to the campus, celebrities throughout these years?
Well, of course, Seberg was the next one who was kind of a disaster, to say the least.
But in education, we had several fine ones in the centennial year.
Butts, R. Freeman Butts of Columbia.
was one of our speakers.
He's still living, as far as I know, must be in his 90s.
And we had Brody, a foundation man from Illinois, who gave a great presentation.
We're not on tape now, are we?
Yes, yes, yes.
I don't want to hesitate.
In the old days, long-distance phone calls made me so nervous because I wanted to be sure to get it all out in three minutes.
Oh, no, no, that's no worry.
We had just marvelous speakers here, and faculty.
Remember the yearly lecture of an outstanding faculty member?
I remember this group in 1972 or 73 called the Antiquarians, and Bill Allen got that going.
I have some of his letters that are just absolutely hilarious as he introduces the next group.
He's back at L.A.
I heard from him recently.
His wife died and he's been not well.
Now who became your, during all these years, who became your closest faculty friends?
Well, Glenn Johnson, I think Bob Schutz.
Bob Schutz died four years ago.
And I was divorced in 1978, and so that hurt my social life.
And then I remarried.
the lady taught at Pan American and she never lived here, so that was a little bit...
So I kind of went out of the social swim.
But on campus, who were your close friends?
Well, Dick Costas always.
We now
have a knot-holers club with Tom Chandler, who's, of course, suffering from Parkinson's, and Clint Phillips, and a few others.
And we meet every two weeks to discuss the state of baseball.
But Dick Cost, over the years, was my best friend outside of the department.
Of course, Bill Allen, when he was here.
We were classmates together at Cornell.
But every faculty member was very friendly.
And I got to know a lot of them through tact.
But then in the last 10 or 15 years, I've been out of the swim.
Looking back over all these years, what were some of the happiest moments you recall as an Aggie faculty member?
Well, I think I was always happy.
I worked hard, but I always felt very happy here.
There was something about A&M that the students reinforced this.
What contributed to all that positive feeling?
I don't even when I was divorced.
I mean, I went through a terrible depression.
But I just still had the feeling of belonging to a great university.
But of course, happiness is a state of mind which probably is not completely environmental.
I think I just had that kind of nature.
But these have been the happiest times of my life.
Now other happy experiences, I think probably a very happy experience is every semester when the semester's over.
And you can say,
sort of sigh and say, well now I don't have to get ready for the next day right away.
Those were all happy times.
And all the happy memories of students.
These students were very fine.
Have there been times when a student would, a former student would write you a letter or stop you somewhere and thank you for?
Well, oh yes.
Since I've been retired, students remember me better than when they had me.
How do they?
Well, they tell my wife what a fine teacher I was or something like that.
I remember when I won the teaching award, I had students write me and ask for money, jokingly.
You're talking about this— No, no, it was just the $2,000 award.
But I didn't get a watch.
How did you learn you had won that?
Not until I was sitting in the faculty meeting, and I was very embarrassed because one time I didn't wear a suit coat.
And I had no idea until Brian Cole said, he's famous for pontificating.
And with that coined word, I suddenly thought, gosh, that's striking pretty close.
That was, I think, definitely the happiest.
I also won a teaching award when the civilian students had an award earlier in the 70s.
But yes, I think that was the happiest time, because we generally wonder if we ever have done any good and if we can be recognized for anything.
And that was monumental.
Of all your research, what were you most proud?

I think probably of my creation of the sociobiography, which I was trying to develop as a new genre for a combination of biography and sociology, at the development of the International Society for Educational Biography.
And I think that has become important in the long run.
The society is still going strong, not to anything I'm doing.
Right now I'm mainly just doing fiction.
I've gone back to what I wanted to do before I went into teaching.
Are you publishing any of it?
No, I haven't published anything.
I like to write more than I try to figure out the markets, but I'm writing short stories now because my memory is getting shorter.
As you look back on these years at A&M,
Did the College of Education miss any opportunities?
Are there any things that now you think could have been done that for some reason didn't get done?
Well, as I say, we could have had a stronger
foundations development, which to me is so important.
If we're going to develop a profession, I think we need to have more theoretical roots and a better understanding of what has been done rather than keep reinventing the wheel.
We never really took off the ground there, except for
the things I did, and I made a very small contribution.
But I think the education department was very, very strong, and I think what they were doing was outstanding.
The problem of education, of course, is that it's much too complex for anybody.
Everybody's different, and we don't have a single law.
of gravity.
And even gravity, I understand, doesn't work all the time anymore either.
But it's such a very complex field that I think it's not a science.
And I think attempts to make it a science are worthy.
But it still comes back down to its humanistic roots, I think.
And that is what the Foundation's tried to cultivate.
As far as you know, if we ranked all the programs in education in the nation today, where would A&M be?
and relative general grouping?
I think right up at the top.
I don't think there's any question about that.
Of course, I haven't been keeping up for the last nine years.
But I think it's my experiences at Columbia, Brooklyn College, and my trips to Stanford and Iowa and other conventions.
I think what we're doing here is right up at the very top.
If we could group all the people together, call them back, all the people that you dealt with here in education and elsewhere in the university, to whom would you be most grateful?
Who would you want to thank most?
Not just students.
Not just students.
Well, I think that's a very fine question.
There's so many people that we would need to thank.
I would thank Glenn Johnson for bringing me here, and Dean Hubert for helping me grow.
Demanding that I grow is a nice way of them.
And so many of the colleagues.
But I think, again, it's our students that make the whole thing work.
And I would like to thank all my students.
I've had some very good ones, and of course I'm proud of most of them.
I didn't always know what I was trying to get at, and sometimes I didn't either, but I'd like to thank them.
I've just about run out of questions.
Are there some topics we have not covered that we should have?
No.
What extra departmental activities?
What service groups were you?
Well, I did work with the Rutter Lecture Series and then on the Centennial Committee with you.
And one of the lecture series that
I developed along with another person.
It was the Aiken.
It was our Senator Aiken.
Gilmer Aiken?
Gilmer Aiken.
But it also had, I put it down.
My memory is just not trustworthy.
Stennett.
Stennett.
He was one of our very famous.
at administration, who was the founder of so many evaluation developments and higher standards in education, Stennett Aiken.
Aiken Stennett.
We developed a lecture series and brought in Maxine Green, who was a cult figure in education.
and Kineller from UCLA.
It didn't continue, but I was very proud of work in that area.
And, of course, my TACT activities outside of the College of Education.
Well, I was president of TACT when the Senate came along, and I was surprised the Senate didn't contact us on that.
But TACT was always small, maybe 100 people.
Then I, of course, with advancing age,
slowed down.
I've just tried to keep up with research in the field of history of children and also in qualitative research, the key to it.
I think biography is essentially as close as we can get to good solid qualitative research.
If you were brought in as a consultant to the department and then to the college today, what advice would you give them
for A&M's programs to be even better in EDC&I and the College of Education.
What advice would you give them?
Well, I don't think I'd want to give advice.
I would like to ask what we mean by better.
I was also on this evaluation committee for the university, and our service and research and teaching was our major field.
Well, what is better teaching?
I wouldn't advise on that.
Although I have various theories, but I think we would have to have a lot of alternative teaching devices because people are so different.
Research, I would advise continual stressing of research.
I might advise that there some could be more teaching professors who would love teaching and not require them to do a lot of research, give them more teaching.
and if they love that, and not have them research or lose their position because they haven't published.

And as far as service is concerned, I think we need to get closer and closer to the community and to the nation, not being dependent upon the nation for funding all the time, but at least to make sure that it's relevant.
But I would more like to have them tell me what they're doing.
I don't think I'd be a very good consultant.
I'm too indirect.
In terms of the sheer size of the program, would you suggest any changes there?
I think it's gotten a little bit too big.
I yearned for those days when we were a family.
We wanted to be a community of scholars and a community of students.
And it's hard to do in a big fashion.
And yet, it's more economical.
I think it might be possible to develop maybe smaller communities within.
Of course, our colleges are that.
But within the colleges, try to develop some centers for community interest to develop.
But I think when you get up to over 40,000, it becomes more like a factory, even without the whistle.
All right, then, I've got only two left.

And the next last one is, if someone walked up to you and gave you a check for a million dollars with one requirement that you had to pass it on to Texas A&M, what would you want A&M to do with that money which you gave them?
You can make the decision.
Well, initially, my first thought would be scholarships for needy students.
In what areas?
Well, of course, education is my field, but if I had a million dollars to give to the university, I think it should be divided into various areas as scholarships for any
in each of the colleges.
When you said for needy students.
Well, let me take that back.
I think for outstanding students.
Yes, the best.
All right, the last question.
What feelings do you carry in your heart for Texas A&M today?
Well, to me, this is the height of my career.
And I want to stay here as long as I can and be part of it.
I'm still a professor emeritus.
I still have an office.
And I'm still on a committee or two.
Probably I'll never finish.
But I'd like to finish here, which I consider the best part of my career and life.
That's a good thing.
